newsitem.title: USA: Mafia said shifting focus to white collar crime.
newsitem.headline: Mafia said shifting focus to white collar crime.

text.p: Mafia families in the Northeast United States are shifting increasingly to white collar crime, The New York Times quoting law enforcement officials reported Monday.
It said the new Mafia focus was mainly in the areas of health insurance, prepaid telephone cards, an industry that grosses about $1 billion a year, and small Wall Street brokerage houses.

"They are analagous to companies in Chapter 11 bankruptcy," Lewis Schiliro, chief of the FBI's criminal division in New York, told the paper. "They are still in business but many of their old moneymaking bases have dried up and they are moving into new industries to fill the void."

The paper said federal and local law officials were investigating efforts by the Genovese, Gambino and Colombo crime families to coordinate frauds through initial public offerings in the over-the-counter market handled by small brokerage firms.

A Long Island businessman who asked not to be identified told the paper that mobsters offer loans to brokers, forcing them in exchange to sell low-priced shares of a company before its stock is offered to the public.

The report also said 12 men accused of being members of the Genovese family were arrested in August after setting up a New Jersey company that investigators said was used to extract excessive payments from health plan administrators.
